Posts.EditableText: Why don't any games coded in pre-3.0 ASL work in Quest 3.5? I thought it was backwards-compatible. The variables don't work and you cannot take/use/say. I'm mentioning this because it says in the manual that Quest is backwards-compatible. I wanted to clarify this.
Posts.HTML: Why don't any games coded in pre-3.0 ASL work in Quest 3.5? I thought it was backwards-compatible. The variables don't work and you cannot take/use/say. I'm mentioning this because it says in the manual that Quest is backwards-compatible. I wanted to clarify this.

Posts.EditableText: Are you sure the games you're playing actually support taking, using and speaking to whatever it is you're trying to take, use or speak to? I've just loaded up Quest 3.5 with The Adventures of Koww the Magician - a game coded for Quest 2.0 - and it plays fine.
Posts.HTML: Are you sure the games you're playing actually support taking, using and speaking to whatever it is you're trying to take, use or speak to? I've just loaded up Quest 3.5 with The Adventures of Koww the Magician - a game coded for Quest 2.0 - and it plays fine.

Posts.EditableText: I was using my old games (Earthquake, ugh) and some other less-than-average game from the archives. I think I tried a quest 1.x as well.
Posts.HTML: I was using my old games (Earthquake, ugh) and some other less-than-average game from the archives. I think I tried a quest 1.x as well.

Posts.EditableText: Hmm, there aren't any Quest 1.x games in the archive... My guess is they probably don't implement the basic things that they should, like giving descriptions to objects. A quick look at the ASL code should let you see if they're badly designed games or not.
Posts.HTML: Hmm, there aren't any Quest 1.x games in the archive... My guess is they probably don't implement the basic things that they should, like giving descriptions to objects. A quick look at the ASL code should let you see if they're badly designed games or not.

Posts.EditableText: its backwards compatible because im assuming things have been ADDED to the program, and nothing has been changed, therefore there is no reason why anything shouldnt work.
Posts.HTML: its backwards compatible because im assuming things have been ADDED to the program, and nothing has been changed, therefore there is no reason why anything shouldnt work.
